name: Phoneme
definition: The smallest unit of sound in our spoken language. Pronouncing the word cat involves blending three phonemes: /k/ /ae/ /t/.

name: Grapheme
definition: A written letter or a group of letters representing one speech sound. Examples: b, sh, ch, igh, eigh.

name: Onset
definition: An initial consonant or consonant cluster. In the word name, n is the onset; in the word blue, bl is the onset.

name: Rime
definition: The vowel or vowel and consonant(s) that follow the onset. In the word name, ame is the rime.

name: Digraph
definition: Two letters that represent one speech sound (diphthong). Examples: sh, ch, th, ph.

name: Vowel Digraph
definition: Two letters that together make one vowel sound. Examples: ai, oo, ow.

name: Schwa
definition: The vowel sound sometimes heard in an unstressed syllable and that most often sounds like /uh/ or the short /u/ sound. Example: the “a” in again or balloon. All English vowels have a schwa sound.

name: Morpheme
definition: The smallest meaningful units of language. The word cat is a morpheme. Not all morphemes stand alone as words; some are attached to words, usually as affixes. These are called bound morphemes. Examples include: non-, -est, -ing, -er, -ion.
